speaker: Frank
text: Let's get started. How long have you been using Canva?

speaker: Michelle
text: I started using Canva as a freshman in high school. That's probably year 5 or year 6 now.

speaker: Frank
text: How were you introduced to Canva?

speaker: Michelle
text: I was in student council in high school, and they told me I had to make a flyer for the first time as a freshman. I needed to find out how to make flyers, and then I realized Canva existed. It was probably other students or a teacher who told me. I didn't have Canva Pro at that point.

speaker: Frank
text: When did you get Canva Pro?

speaker: Michelle
text: I was a sophomore or a junior when my student council advisor, the student activities manager, figured out that you could do a classroom. She gave all of us the Canva code so we could be on her classroom.

speaker: Frank
text: How frequent would you say your use for Canva is?

speaker: Michelle
text: In different stages of my life, it's been different. My junior year, I was secretary for student council, and all I did was make flyers, so I made more than one every week. Now I make about one or two flyers a week.

speaker: Frank
text: What's your major? Do you do any design-related stuff?

speaker: Michelle
text: No, my major's Economics and Global Affairs.

speaker: Frank
text: So when you go to the professional world, you probably wouldn't be looking at roles like social media manager or design-heavy positions?

speaker: Michelle
text: Probably not.

speaker: Frank
text: When you used Canva before to make those flyers, what drove you to use Canva? What made you stay?

speaker: Michelle
text: I'm not a graphic design person. Those people gravitate towards Adobe or Creative Cloud. For me, with no experience, that's too technical. Canva is great because you can get somewhat technical with experience—background remover and other features—but it's still user-friendly. I just play around with it, and that's all the training I need.

speaker: Frank
text: Do you see yourself using Canva more or less in the future?

speaker: Michelle
text: I really like nonprofits, and they use it a lot even if you're not a design person. For example, I interned with my El Paso Community Foundation two summers ago. I didn't go in for graphic design, but when they found out I could make a flyer, that's all I was doing. It's not my experience or interest, but it comes with the kind of work I'm interested in—nonprofit work or smaller local organizations.

speaker: Frank
text: So the biggest value Canva provides you is that it's easy to use, and since you're not a graphic design-type person, you can still make things look good and aesthetic?

speaker: Michelle
text: Yes. I also like how many pre-made designs they have. There's no barrier to entry. Once you get more familiar with it, you can look through designs for ideas, replicate them, and change what you want. I'm not limited to what they have but can still take ideas.

speaker: Frank
text: Have you ever used any other designing software like Figma?

speaker: Michelle
text: No. I might have tried one once, and I didn't like it. I don't remember why. It must have been not as easy, and I never went back.

speaker: Frank
text: When I was using Canva, one frustration was transferring from one school account to another. I couldn't bulk copy my templates. Did that happen to you?

speaker: Michelle
text: No. I always used my Gmail because I knew my high school account would be deleted. I never used my school district account for Canva, Quizlet, or other things.

speaker: Frank
text: When you went to Yale, did you continue using your personal Gmail?

speaker: Michelle
text: For emails, I use my Yale account. For accounts not connected to other people, I use my Gmail. It keeps my Yale inbox cleaner.

speaker: Frank
text: When you're using Canva, did you have any frustrations?

speaker: Michelle
text: I haven't run into anything that frustrates me. If I wanted to transfer designs, that might be frustrating, but I've never needed to do that.

speaker: Frank
text: What do you think Canva could do better? Is there a feature that could be improved or added?

speaker: Michelle
text: Maybe a training feature. I've had to mess around with things until I figured them out. Maybe they do have a training thing, and I haven't looked at it, but a crash course or option to revisit it would be helpful. For example, I didn't discover the background remover until year 3 or 4. It would have been useful to know earlier.
